Package com.github.kbnt.java14.se

Class SwitchExpressions

java.lang.Object
com.github.kbnt.java14.se.SwitchExpressions
public class SwitchExpressions
extends java.lang.Object
In this example set we assume that we are working on a calendar application, following the same thought process as the snippets in JEP 361 (Switch Expressions). The main idea is that we want to have meetings every other day, starting Mondays. With that idea in mind, we do some variations.
Note: at the moment of writing this material, as a developer you still had to use the --enable-preview JVM option.
Author:
Chris T

    Arrow labels open the capability for execution blocks, scope, no fall-through and expressions.
    void example03SwitchAsExpressionAndYield()
    Since now we get access to block codes, let's collect the result of the execution in that block.
    void example04SwitchAsExpressionExhaustiveness()
    When we leverage the switch statement as an expression to collect the result, we need to be exhaustive.

  • Method Details

    • main

      public static void main​(java.lang.String[] args)

    • example00PreJava12

      public void example00PreJava12()
      This example shows a classic switch statement. It is provided just to have a starting point for comparison (don't expect anything surprising here!).

    • example01MultiCase

      public void example01MultiCase()
      With the new syntax, we can "condense" some of the case statements.

    • example02ArrowLabels

      public void example02ArrowLabels()
      Arrow labels open the capability for execution blocks, scope, no fall-through and expressions.

    • example03SwitchAsExpressionAndYield

      public void example03SwitchAsExpressionAndYield()
      Since now we get access to block codes, let's collect the result of the execution in that block.

    • example04SwitchAsExpressionExhaustiveness

      public void example04SwitchAsExpressionExhaustiveness()
      When we leverage the switch statement as an expression to collect the result, we need to be exhaustive. In plain words, that means that we need to show to the compiler that we covered all the cases - otherwise the variable we declare might remain uninitialized and the compiler will generate an error.
